question:
Directions:

Directions : In the following passage, some of the words have been left out and replaced by blanks represented with letters. First, read the passage and try to understand what it is about. Then, fill in the blanks as per the questions given.

Global warming, water scarcity, population growth, rising food prices, urbanization, and other socio-economic factors __(A)__ significant threats to agriculture and food security in the 21st century. One of the biggest challenges facing the world today is __(B)__ hunger and feeding the world's expanding population. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations declared 2023 as the International Year of Millets. In India, for centuries, millets were the staple crops, but __(C)__ they were replaced by high-yielding varieties of wheat and rice in the identified green revolution regions, which led to their marginalization. Compared to rice and wheat, small millets are superior in nutrition and offer inexpensive minerals, protein, and vitamins to __(D)__ the health of poor communities around the Asia-Pacific region. Additionally, they are almost free of grain storage pests and have a longer storage life. Due to their untapped potential, grain yield and nutritional benefits, millets have the potential to become important future food crops, especially in the more challenging rainfed areas. __(E)__ India was once a dominant producer of these grains, recent years have seen Africa emerge as a significant player in millet production. Previously, millets covered 35 million hectares of farmland, but this has now dwindled to 15 million hectares. The limited policy support for millet farming and consumption has further __(F)__ their expansion. Moreover, with rice and wheat being the staple grains in India and readily available, millets struggle to gain a competitive foothold in the market.



Which of the following words fits in blank A?
solution:
The sentence with blank A describes an ongoing fact about socio-economic factors acting as threats to agriculture and food security. Since the subject ("Global warming, water scarcity, population growth, rising food prices, urbanization, and other socio-economic factors") is plural, the verb must agree with it. The plural verb "pose" is the correct choice because it follows subject-verb agreement in the simple present tense, which is used to express general truths or facts.

Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

"Processes" - Incorrect, as it is a noun. Also, as a verb, it does not fit the blank as it is a singular verb, and we require a plural verb.

"Imposed" - Incorrect, as it is in the past tense and does not match the present-tense context of the sentence.

"Prose" - Incorrect, as it is a noun referring to written or spoken language, irrelevant here.

"Possessing" - Incorrect, as it is the present participle form, which does not fit grammatically. It requires a helping verb before it which is absent in the given sentence.

Note: Subject-verb agreement is a grammatical rule that states that a subject and its verb must agree in number and sometimes in person. For example, a singular subject takes a singular verb, and a plural subject takes a plural verb.

question:
Select the phrase/connector/word-pair from the given three options to form a single sentence from the two sentences given below, implying the same meaning as expressed in the original sentences. The phrase/connector must appear at the beginning of the final sentence.

I. Measures for better protection were announced for tiger reserves.

II. Wildlife societies and activists were happy.

(i) Since

(ii) In spite of

(iii) As
solution:
'Since' and 'as' indicate a cause and effect relationship. 'In spite of' is used to indicate a contrast in expectation. This cannot combine the sentences as the resultant sentence would not make sense logically. 'Since' and 'as' can link the two sentences, as the second sentence can act as the result of the first sentence. B is the right answer.

"As/Since measures for better protection was announced for tiger reserves, wildlife societies and activists were happy."

question:
Select the phrase/connector/word-pair from the given three options to form a single sentence from the two sentences given below, implying the same meaning as expressed in the original sentences. The phrase/connector must appear at the beginning of the final sentence.

I. Historically, the rate of success of start-ups is very less.

II. The group of entrepreneurs decided that they will take their chance.

(i) Though

(ii) Particularly

(iii) Since
solution:
'Though' is used to indicate contrast in expectation. 'Particularly' is used to single out a subject to which a statement is especially applicable. 'Since' is used to signify a cause and effect relationship. The first sentence tells us that the rate of success of start-ups is less. The second sentence tells us that some people want to take a chance in spite of the uninspiring statistics. So, only 'though' can link these sentences. A is the right answer.

"Though historically, the rate of success of start-ups is very less, the group of entrepreneurs decided that they will take their chance."

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the other four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the option containing the part with the error. If none of the parts contains error, mark 'No error' as your answer.

As I travel to different countries I (A) often get a chance to talk with (B) students, and when I do I'm often (C) very impressed by there passion for helping (D) solve some of the world's toughest problems (E).
solution:
The error lies in part D. 'There' is an adverb used to show location/position of the noun/pronoun it refers to; but its use renders the sentence meaningless. We need to use the determiner 'their' to show that the speaker in the sentence is impressed by the passion of the students.

Answer is option (b).

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the other four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the option containing the part with the error. If none of the parts contains error, mark 'No error' as your answer.

Although I strongly disagree with what Mr. Ridley (A) says in these pages about some of (B) the critical issues facing the world today, (C) but his wider narrative is based on two ideas (D) that are very important and powerful (E).
solution:
We see 'although' and 'but' being used in the given sentence. 'Although' is a conjunction that is synonymous with 'but' and hence the sentence shows redundancy. As part A is given error-free, the error must be in part D. Eliminating 'but' altogether resolves the redundancy and makes the sentence error-free.

Answer is option (d).

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given, divided into five parts. The part given in bold is grammatically and contextually correct. Out of the other four parts, one part may contain an error. Mark the option containing the part with the error. If none of the parts contains error, mark 'No error' as your answer.

In Energy Transitions, Smil explains the three (A) great energy transition, which occurred over (B) the last several hundred years and included (C) the shift from wood to coal, (D) and the rise of oil and natural gas (E).
solution:
The sentence talks about a particular energy transition (a singular noun) and explains that it occurred over the last several hundred years. Hence the use of cardinal number 'three' (plural) to refer to the energy transition is incorrect. 'Third' (ordinal number) would be more suitable (in place of 'three') in the sentence.

Answer is option (b).

question:
In the question below, a sentence is given with four words highlighted in bold. One of these four words may be either wrongly spelt or inappropriate in the context of the sentence. Find out the word, which is wrongly spelt or inappropriate, if any. If all the words are correctly spelt and appropriate in the context of the sentence, mark 'All are correct' as your answer.

Many shipping companies do not report (A) incidents (B) of pyracy (C), for fear of raising their insurance rates (D).
solution:
Word C is incorrectly spelt. The correct spelling is:

Piracy - the crime of attacking ships in order to steal from them.

Hence, the answer is option c).

question:
In the question given below, a sentence is given with four words highlighted in bold. One of these four words may either be wrongly spelt or inappropriate in the context of the sentence. Find out the word, which is wrongly spelt or inappropriate, if any. If all the words are correctly spelt and appropriate in the context of the sentence, mark 'All are correct' as your answer.

The town is frequently refered(A) to as a model residential(B) suburb; its budgets(C) are very large, and its schools are excellent(D).
solution: The correct spelling of the word (A) is referred (refer to: (of a word, phrase, or symbol) describe or denote; have as a referent). The rest need not be changed. Hence, option (a) is the correct answer.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with two words highlighted in bold. Select the option given below that can replace both words in bold to make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct and mark that as your answer. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No correction required', as the answer.

Despite his busy schedule, he was determine to complete the project before the deadline.
solution:
Here, "determine" is incorrect as we need a participle form of the verb after "was".

The words "busy" and "determine" can both be replaced with "committed", which correctly conveys that he was both occupied with work and firmly dedicated to completing the project.

• Option (b) "occupied" - Incorrect, as it conveys being busy but does not express determination.

• Option (c) "engaged" - Incorrect, as it means involved in an activity but lacks the sense of strong determination.

• Option (d) "persistent" - Incorrect, as it implies perseverance but does not replace "busy" correctly.

• Option (e) "supremely" - Incorrect, as an adverb cannot be used to modify the noun "schedule".

Thus, the best answer is option (a) committed.

question:
In the following question, a sentence is given with two words highlighted in bold. Select the option given below that can replace both words in bold to make the sentence grammatically and contextually correct and mark that as your answer. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No correction required', as the answer.

As she walked in the soft radiant of the evening, she was relieved that her backpack felt surprisingly weightless, making the journey more pleasant.
solution:
The given sentence: "As she walked in the soft radiant of the evening, she was relieved that her backpack felt surprisingly weightless, making the journey more pleasant."

Issue with "radiant": "Radiant" is an adjective, but the sentence requires a noun (something that describes the glow or illumination of the evening).

Correction: "Light" (noun) fits well: "soft light of the evening."

"Weightless" is correct but can be replaced: "Light" (adjective) also means "not heavy," which makes sense in context.

Thus, replacing both words with "light" makes the sentence correct: "As she walked in the soft light of the evening, she was relieved that her backpack felt surprisingly light, making the journey more pleasant."

Hence, option (e) is the answer.

question:
Which of the following phrases (I), (II), and (III) given below the sentence should replace the phrase printed in bold to make the sentence grammatically correct? Choose the best option among the five given alternatives that reflects the correct phrase to be used in the sentence. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No Improvement', as the answer.

The idea that walking could had abundant side effects on mental health, creativity, and well-being goes back decades, with a series of tests on rodents.

I. walk might have enormous inflictions

II. walk could impart multiple implications

III. walking can hugely impact
solution:
In the phrase given in bold, the modal verb 'could' is incorrectly followed by the past tense verb 'had', which is incorrect.

In options I and II, the verb form of the word 'walk' makes the phrase grammatically incorrect because, the word has to be in the gerund form, which can also act as noun in the sentence, which is required in the context of the sentence. Since both these options are in the base form, thus cannot be used and thus negated.

Option III, 'walking can hugely impact' is the grammatical phrase which matches the context of the sentence and can thus replace the incorrect phrase in the sentence.

Hence, the correct answer is option (b).

Note:

Modal verb: A verb used with another verb to express an idea such as possibility that is not expressed by the main verb. The modal verbs in English are "can," "could," "may," "might," "must," "ought," "shall," "should," "will," and "would." They do not change their form (spelling) and they have no infinitive or participle (past/present). Example: I can speak Spanish. Here 'can' expresses the ability of the person to speak (main verb) Spanish. This ability cannot be expressed by the main verb 'speak'.

question:
Which of the following phrases (I), (II), and (III) given below the sentence should replace the phrase printed in bold to make the sentence grammatically correct? Choose the best option among the five given alternatives that reflects the correct phrase(s) to be used in the sentence. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No Improvement', as the answer.

I eliminated places that was to be closed when I passed by, including farmers' markets that are open for just four hours per week.

I. I struck down places that, being slated for closure, no longer warranted consideration

II. I zeroed down places where closure was impending

III. He eliminated places for which closure was to be
solution:
In the phrase given in bold, the noun 'places' is incorrectly followed by the singular verb 'was', which leads to an error in the Subject-Verb Agreement. So, the phrase needs to be replaced.

Statement I is contextually and grammatically correct and hence can replace the incorrect phrase in the sentence.

Statement II is incorrect because 'zeroed down' is an incorrect phrasal verb.

Statement III is incorrect because it starts with the subjective pronoun 'He' but in the sentence, the subjective pronoun 'I' is given, thereby making the phrase grammatically incompatible with the given sentence.

Hence, the correct answer is option (a).

Note:

Subjective Pronouns: The pronouns I, you, we, he, she, it, and they are known as subjective pronouns because they act as the subjects of verbs: We went to the party.

Subject-Verb Agreement: Matching up singular or plural subjects with singular or plural forms of a verb is part of the process called agreement. This can be understood better by the examples given: - "She likes cooking." [singular subject and verb] -- "They like to cook vegetables." [plural subject and verb]

Phrasal verb: A phrase that consists of a verb with a preposition or adverb or both, the meaning of which is different from the meaning of its separate parts. Example: She has always looked down on me. Here, the phrasal verb 'to look down on someone' doesn't mean that you are looking down from a higher place at someone who is below you; it means that you think that you are better than someone.

question:
Which of the following phrases (I), (II), and (III) given below the sentence should replace the phrase printed in bold to make the sentence grammatically correct? Choose the best option among the five given alternatives that reflects the correct phrase(s) to be used in the sentence. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No Improvement', as the answer.

The real danger comes from passengers on previous flights leaving to destinations with peanut residue on the seats, trays, floor and entertainment screens.

I. previous flights that were left with peanut residue

II. flights previous, having peanut residue onboard

III. flights that had peanut residue from previous passengers
solution:
In the phrase given in bold, the term 'destinations with peanut residue' projects an incorrect context, stating that the previous flights' destinations were places with peanut residue, which changes the meaning of the sentence. So, the phrase needs to be replaced.

Statement I is incorrect because in the sentence the noun that does the action of leaving peanut residue is stated as passengers of previous flights however, in this phrase the use of the relative pronoun 'that' in the place of 'who' makes the phrase grammatically incorrect.

Statement II is incorrect because of the misplaced comma and incorrect phrase structure; "having peanut residue onboard" is unclear and grammatically incorrect.

Statement III is contextually and grammatically correct and can thus replace the incorrect phrase given in the sentence.

Hence, the correct answer is option (e).

Note:

Relative pronouns are pronouns that head an adjective clause. The relative pronouns in English are "that," "which," "who," "whom," and "whose". They are used to form complex sentences and provide additional information about a noun. Examples of relative pronouns include:

• Who: Refers to a person (the noun/pronoun/subject which does the action)

• Whom: Refers to the object (the noun or pronoun that receives the action)

• Whose: Used to show possession of something or someone

question:
In the question given below, rearrange the parts of the sentences in the correct order, and mark the answer accordingly.

ruins, Komodo dragons, and coral reefs (A) / the Indonesian islands of Bali, Java, and Nusa (B) / strung between the islands of Sumatra and Timor-Leste, (C) / Tenggara are ripe with coffee farms, Buddhist temple (D) /.
solution: 'Buddhist temple' of part D can perfectly relate to 'ruins' of part A, making DA a mandatory pair. This will eliminate both options a) & b). Following option (d) will not lead to a coherent sentence, as parts A & B together will not make a meaningful sense. Hence, option (c) will be the correct answer.

question:
In the question given below, rearrange the parts of the sentence in the correct order, and choose the correct option.

the U.S. Commerce Department, citing national (A)/ to its "entity list," preventing companies from supplying (B)/ U.S.-origin technology to Huawei without U.S. government approval (C)/ security concerns, said last month it was adding Huawei and its affiliates (D)
solution:
BC forms a pair as B and C tell what the companies are prevented from supplying. 'Citing national security concerns (AD)' should quickly be checked for a pair as it is a well-used term and AD is indeed forming a pair that will start the sentence. ADBC is the correct arrangement. Option (c) is the correct answer.

The sentence tells us that the U.S. Commerce Department because of security concerns added Huawei and its affiliates in a lost that prevented them from supplying U.S.-origin technology to Huawei without U.S. government approval.

question:
Directions:

Directions : Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions that follow.

Recently, America's surgeon-general called vaping an epidemic among young people, criticising in particular products with "kid-friendly" flavours, such as cinnamon and vanilla. Many countries, including India, have already banned e-cigarettes. The devices use an electric charge to vaporise a dose of nicotine (accompanied, often, by various flavouring chemicals). The composition of the vapour varies between brands. Its main ingredients - propylene glycol and glycerol - are thought to be mostly harmless when inhaled. But that is not certain. Nitrosamines, a carcinogenic family of chemicals, have been found in e-cigarette vapour, albeit at levels low enough to be deemed insignificant. Metallic particles from the device's heating element, such as nickel and cadmium, are also a concern. High exposure to these can increase the risk of cancer. Some studies have found that the vapour contains high levels of nasty chemicals such as formaldehyde, acetaldehyde and acrolein, all derived from the other ingredients that have been exposed to high temperatures. It also contains free radicals, compounds that get readily oxidised and can damage tissue or DNA. Then there is nicotine. Besides being addictive, it is known to have an adverse effect all around the body. The main concern is its effects on children. Work in animals suggests that exposure to nicotine at an early age could make users more susceptible to other addictive substances later in life.

This sounds worrying, but e-cigarettes are nowhere near as nasty as their combustible cousins. Cigarette smoke contains about 70 carcinogens, as well as carbon monoxide (a poison), particulates, toxic heavy metals such as cadmium and arsenic, oxidising chemicals and many other organic compounds. Instead of the thousands of different compounds in cigarette smoke, e-cigarette vapour probably contains merely hundreds. And cigarettes may be more addictive than some e-cigarettes because they deliver other chemicals along with nicotine. For example, tobacco smoke amplifies the addictive nature of nicotine by inhibiting monoamine oxidase, an enzyme that helps break down the dopamine (a pleasure hormone) that nicotine releases in the brain.

Regulators and politicians are right to worry about the long-term effects of e-cigarettes, but widespread bans risk forgoing the potential health benefits of people turning to e-cigarettes as a substitute for the conventional sort. The proportion of America's high-school students vaping fell from 27.5% in 2019 to 19.6% last year, according to the National Youth Tobacco Survey. But smoking still kills 480,000 Americans every year, and 8 million people worldwide. That means regulators must strike a fine balance: help smokers quit while deterring a new generation of nicotine addicts.



According to the passage, why cigarettes are more harmful than e-cigarettes?

I. Cigarette smoke contains about 70 carcinogens but e-cigarettes contain less than a third of these.

II. Cigarettes are probably more addictive than e-cigarettes.

III. Nitrosamines, a carcinogenic compound is found in negligible quantities in e-cigarettes but in abnormally huge amounts in cigarettes.
solution:
Considering the second sentence of the second paragraph: 'Cigarette smoke contains about 70 carcinogens, as well as carbon monoxide (a poison), particulates, toxic heavy metals such as cadmium and arsenic, oxidising chemicals and many other organic compounds.' The passage does not explicitly mention about the presence of carcinogens in e-cigarettes. Thus, statement I is incorrect.

Considering the following sentence from the second paragraph: 'And cigarettes may be more addictive than some e-cigarettes because they deliver other chemicals along with nicotine.' It suggests that statement II is correct.

Considering the following sentence from the first paragraph: 'Nitrosamines, a carcinogenic family of chemicals, have been found in e-cigarette vapour, albeit at levels low enough to be deemed insignificant.' The passage does not explicitly mention about the presence of nitrosamines in conventional cigarettes. Thus, statement III is incorrect.

Hence, the answer is option a).

'Detrimental' means 'tending to cause harm'. Thus, it is opposite in meaning to 'harmless'. 'Benign' means 'not harmful in effect'. Other options are not related in meaning to the given word.

question:
In the question below, a sentence is given, divided into parts and jumbled, which when arranged will form a logical and coherent sentence. Rearrange the parts to form a meaningful sentence and choose the option that represents the correct arrangement.

A. were formed by a membrane of skin that was connected to the hand by an elongated fourth finger, not unlike the fleshy wings of bats

B. the order Pterosauria, which includes all flying reptiles that lived in the Mesozoic Era, Pterosaurs

C. since as early as 1834 the scientific community has considered pterodactyl an outdated informal name for members of

D. were the first reptiles capable of flight and the first vertebrates to successfully fly, a feat they accomplished

E. by using strong forelegs to launch their bodies into the air and their wings
solution:
After reading all the parts, we find that 'C' should be the first part as it started the discussion about pterodactyl, an outdated informal name for a species. The members of the order Pterosauria and their characteristics are further described in part 'B' so it will be the next part of the sentence. The next part should talk about 'Pterosaurs', but 'A' talks about some formation of skin, so 'D' should be the third part as it talks about 'Pterosaurs' being the first reptiles that were capable of flight. How they accomplished flying is mentioned in 'E' so it will be the fourth part of the sentence. 'E' ends with the discussion of wings and how they are formed is described in 'A', so it will be the last part of the sentence.

So, CBDEA is the right order.

Hence, option (a) is correct.

question:
In the question given below, a set of sentences is given, which when properly sequenced, form a coherent paragraph. Arrange the sentences in the correct sequence and answer the questions that follow.

A. Spread over three buildings with 39 galleries, an in-person tour of the Salar Jung Museum in Hyderabad takes about half a day.

B. Starting from 'Birdsong', which will be IME's first physical exhibition in 2022, every exhibition the museum organises will also be available online, promises its director Manasi Prasad.

C. As of July, this year, the museum has digitised more than 47,000 of its artefacts. Now, you need not even be in Hyderabad to view the collections

D. Indian Music Experience (IME), another museum in Bengaluru, meanwhile, has three online exhibitions on Google Arts and Culture, including one dedicated to the late sitar legend Ravi Shankar.

E. It also partnered with Google Arts and Culture to showcase its prominent setup such as the interactive dissection of Raja Ravi Varma's 'Disappointed.'
solution:
The paragraph talks about the new developments in museums. The most apt introduction to the paragraph is A as it introduces us to the huge Salar Jung museum. It is followed by C which talks about the development of digitalisation in museums. E talks about further developments and partnerships between Google Art and the museum. It is followed by D which talks about Indian Music Experience (IME), another museum which has done the same thing. It is followed by B which talks about events happening in the Indian Music Experience (IME). The correct order is ACEDB.

Hence option (a) is correct.

question:
The question consists of five statements labelled A, B, C, D and E which, when logically ordered form a coherent passage. Choose the option that represents the most logical order.

A. One particular area affected by Harvey's ideas was urban planning.

B. The effect was that cities expanded at an exponential rate during the modern era, and city planners adopted Harvey's idea that healthy living required free circulation.

C. In 1628, English physician William Harvey put forth a radical theory: blood circulates.

D. This idea may sound simple, but it flew in the face of centuries of medical orthodoxy, and over the next few centuries, it had an unspeakably large impact on physicians, economists, philosophers, and political thinkers.

E. In the words of sociologist Richard Sennett, "A new master image of the body took form."
solution:
C is first because it is the only independent sentence and initiates the discussion about a theory on blood. D is next as it speaks about the same idea by referring to it as 'this idea'. E follows next as it speaks about the description of the impact of the theory by a sociologist. A is next as it speaks of a particular area being affected by the theory. B is next as it explains what this effect is.

Mandatory pairs-

A-B:

B is after A because A mentions one particular area [urban planning] being affected by the theory, while B explains what that affect is.

The correct order is: CDEAB.

Hence, the correct answer is option (b).

question:
The question consists of five statements labelled A, B, C, D and E which, when logically ordered form a coherent passage. Choose the option that represents the most logical order.

A. Ron Wooten never paid close attention to the local coyotes until they ran off with his dog one night in 2008.

B. The Galveston Island canids are not conventional coyotes; they carry a ghostly genetic legacy: DNA from red wolves, which were declared extinct in the wild in 1980.

C. Their discovery, which came after a determined local resident named Ron Wooten, persuaded scientists to take a closer look at the canids

D. He found the pack, and what remained of his dog, in a nearby field. He was horrified, and he blamed himself for his dog's death.

E. For years, these genes have been hiding in plain sight, tucked away in the seemingly unremarkable animals that scavenged for food behind housing developments
solution:
The paragraph starts with B as it gives the introduction of canids. B is followed by E that mentions 'these genes' which shows a direct connection with B, hence Band E is a pair. C is talking about the discovery and introduces Ron. It is followed by A which describes the incident and a is followed by D, hence CDE is a series.

Hence option (b) is correct.

question:
The question consists of five statements labelled A, B, C, D and E which, when logically ordered form a coherent passage. Choose the option that represents the most logical order.

A. The term "hypoxia" refers to low or depleted oxygen in a water body.

B. Such hypoxic areas are called dead zones.

C. It is often associated with the overgrowth of certain species of algae.

D. Such algae lead to oxygen depletion when they die and decompose in an area.

E. They are called so as they may cause die-offs of fish, corals, and aquatic plants.
solution:
The correct sequence is ACDBE.

Sentence (B) does not start the passage as 'such' hypoxic areas implies there has been previous mention of hypoxic areas in the passage. So, options a) and e) are incorrect.

Sentence (C) cannot start the passage as it does not clarify what is associated with the overgrowth of algae. So, option b) is incorrect as well.

The passage starts with sentence (A), which explains the term hypoxia. It only defines the term. Areas with depleted oxygen have not yet been discussed. So, sentence (B) does not follow (A). Sentence (C) follows (A) and links hypoxia with the overgrowth of certain species of algae. How these algae lead to oxygen depletion in an area is discussed in sentence (D). Then, sentence (B) follows and gives such areas with depleted oxygen a name, i.e., 'dead zone'. Sentence (E) follows and concludes the passage by giving the reason behind naming such areas 'dead zones'.

Hence, the sequence: ACDBE

Hence, option c) is correct.

question:
Which of the following phrases (I), (II), and (III) given below each sentence should replace the phrase printed in bold letters to make the sentence grammatically correct? Choose the best option among the five given alternatives that reflect the correct use of phrase in the context of the grammatically correct sentence. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark (e) i.e., 'No correction required'; as the answer.

It's also important to remember that you are also bodied and not just a brain, and that the capability of your brain isn't entirely disconnected from the state of your body.

I. your bodied

II. there is a body too

III. you are a body
solution: 'Bodied' being an adjective requires a noun which it would be qualifying, which is missing in the highlighted part; hence, it is incorrect. Same logic applies with I. II and III- they fit in the highlighted part grammatically and contextually; hence, (a) is the right answer.

question:
In the question given below, a sentence is given, divided into parts. One of the parts may contain an error. Identify the part that contains the error and mark it as the answer. Ignore errors of punctuation. In case the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No error' as the answer. Note- The words in bold are grammatically and contextually correct.

After analysing data from the 1950s through (A)/ 2019, an international team of scientists (B)/ determined that the average temperature of the (C)/ world's oceans in 2019 was 0.075 degrees Celsius (D)/ higher than the 1981 - 2010 average. (E)
solution: The given sentence is free of grammatical errors and is meaningful. In part (A), the use of 'through', which also means 'up to and including (a particular point in an ordered sequence)', is correct. Hence, option (e) is the correct answer.

question:
Which of the following phrases (I), (II), and (III) given below the sentence should replace the phrase printed in bold to make the sentence grammatically correct? Choose the best option among the five given alternatives that reflect the correct phrase to be used in the sentence. If the sentence is correct as it is, mark 'No correction required', as the answer.

The benefits promise to us by our human rights are extremely varied and some of the most important are grand intangibles such as justice, free speech and freedom of worship.

I. The benefits promised

II. The benefit promised

III. The benefit assured
solution: As the sentence has used 'are' for the subject of the sentence, a plural noun is required as the subject; 'benefits' is correct. Also, a verb in its '-ed' form will fit grammatically after 'benefits' as we talk about an already occurred event. These conditions make II, III and the boldened phrase incorrect. Only I is correct. Option A is the correct answer.

question: In the following question, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Decide which of these sentences is grammatically incorrect and not meaningful and mark the answer accordingly. If none of the sentences contains an error, mark 'All are correct' as your answer.
option_1: Even illusions can be beneficial as they can help launch notions that encourage endeavour in transcendence, magic, religion and science.
option_2: It was the Little Ice Age and bubonic plague that characterized the period between the 14th and the 18th centuries.
option_3: The need for an intellectual and political vanguard has for much of history been taken as common sense, and still today many "democratic" societies remain in thrall to hierarchies of intellect.
option_4: For the past 200 to 300 years, ideas have been in full flow, stimulated by ever-increasing contacts between peoples, and transmitted by accelerating means of communication.
solution: All the given sentences are correct and meaningful. Option E is the correct answer.

question: In the question given below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Choose the one that is grammatically and meaningfully incorrect. In case all the statements are correct, mark 'All are correct' as your answer.
option_1: Studies have found that people who differentiate between their emotions are better able to manage their feelings in more adaptive ways.
option_2: Drones are still largely used for military or policing purposes.
option_3: Only a fraction of sufferers receive treatment because post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is tough to diagnose and treating.
option_4: Discrimination against women and girls is a pervasive and long-running phenomenon that characterises Indian society at every level.
solution: Option c) carries the incorrect statement. 'To' is followed by the base form of the verb (infinitive). Unlike 'diagnose', 'treating' is the progressive form of the verb and must be replaced with the base form of the verb i.e., 'treat' to make the sentence correct. The correct sentence is: "Only a fraction of sufferers receive treatment because post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is tough to diagnose and treat." Hence, c) is the correct answer.

question: In the question given below, four statements are given which may or may not contain an error. Select the one that is grammatically and contextually correct.
option_1: Rolls-Royce is collaborating with Siemens and Airbus to develop a hybrid aircraft in which one of the four gas-turbine engines will be powered sole by electric energy.
option_2: People are tied to existing patterns, infrastructure and systems even as they might want or need to do something different and truly innovative.
option_3: The bitter truth is that human air travel probably won't get much better in the years to came.
option_4: Recalling a memory reactivates a pattern of nerve-cell signalling that mimics the originally experience.
solution: In sentence A, the adverb 'solely' should be used instead of the adjective 'sole', due to the use of the verb 'powered'. In sentence C, 'to come' is the right phrase, which means 'in the future'. It usually follows a noun, like 'years' or 'generations'. In sentence D, the adjective 'original' should replace the adverb 'originally', to qualify the noun 'experience'. B is the right answer.

question:
In the given question, a sentence has been broken into four parts and the parts are jumbled. Choose the option which provides the correct way to re-arrange the parts to form a grammatically and contextually meaningful sentence. If all the parts are correctly placed, mark (e) as your answer.

into a message about the taste of food that gets sent (A) / recognize food and remember how it tastes (B) / to your brain; for example, your eyes help you (C) / your senses gather up all the information and combine it (D)
solution:
AC is pair- A talks about information getting combined into a message and being sent somewhere while C tells us where the same information is sent - to the brain. Only option (c) has that pair; hence, (c) is the right answer.

Your senses gather up all the information and combine it into a message about the taste of food that gets sent to your brain; for example, your eyes help you recognise food and remember how it tastes.

question:
In the question given below, rearrange the parts of the sentence in the correct order, and choose the correct option.

to boys at the age of 14, experts assert (A) / to show signs of depressive symptoms (B) / linked to social media use compared (C) / girls are twice as likely (D)
solution: After looking at all the given parts, we can see that only D can be the starting statement as the other parts require prior information before them. This eliminates all options except a) and d). BC will make a pair in the same order; the subject 'depressive symptoms' requires a verb and an object, which are mentioned in part C- 'linked (verb) to 'social media' (object). Only option d) satisfies both conditions; hence, option d) is the correct answer.

The present age of Pawan and Dhvani is 'P' years and '1.2P' years respectively. Twelve years ago, the age of Pawan is half of the age of Dhvani. Find the respective ratio of the age of Pawan after 13 years and the age of Dhvani after 6 years.
solution:
Present age of Pawan = P years

Present age of Dhvani = 1.2P years

ATQ -

2*(P - 12) = 1.2P - 12

2P - 24 = 1.2P - 12

P = 15

Required ratio = Age of Pawan after 13 years : Age of Dhvani after 6 years

= (15 + 13):(1.2*15 + 6)

= 28:24

= 7:6

question: A, B and C start a business by investing Rs. 4500, Rs. 5400 and Rs. 3600 respectively. A gets 30% of the profit for managing the business and the remaining balance is divided in the ratio of their investments. At the end of the year, A gets Rs. 820 more than B and C together. Find the total profit.
solution:
Ratio of their investments = 4500:5400:3600 = 5:6:4

Let the total profit be Rs. T.

So, 70% of T will be shared in the ratio of investments.

A's share from the profit = 0.3T + (5/15) * 0.7T = 0.3T + 0.7T/3

B's share = (6/15) * 0.7T =4.2T/15

C's share = (4/15) * 0.7T =2.8T/15

Hence, A - (B + C) = 820

0.3T + 0.7T/3 - (4.2T/15 + 2.8T/15) = 820

1.6T/3 - 7T/15 = 820

(8T - 7T)/15 = 820

T = 12300

question: A vessel contains 630 L of milk and water in a ratio of 4: 5. If X L of the mixture is removed and 30 L of milk is mixed, then the ratio of milk to water finally is 10: 11. Find the value of X.

Two buses start from opposite ends of a 480‑km route at the same time and travel toward each other. After 3 hours, they are 120 km apart. If the faster bus is 10 km/h faster than the slower bus, what is the speed of the slower bus?
solution:
In 3 hours, the buses together cover 480 - 120 = 360 km

Combined speed = 360/3 = 120 km/h

Let the slower bus's speed = x km/h

Then the faster bus's speed = (x + 10) km/h

So, x + (x + 10) = 2x + 10 = 120 km/h

=> 2x = 110

=> x = 55 km/h

question: Pipes A, B and C can fill a tank in 30 hours, 24 hours, and Y hours respectively. A leak at the bottom of the tank can empty 3/5th full tank in 24 hours. When all three pipes are open together along with the leak, then the tank gets filled in 15 hours. The value of Y is -
solution:
Time in which the leak can empty the full tank = 24 * 5/3 = 40 hours

When all three pipes are open together along with the leak, then

1/15 = 1/30 + 1/24 + 1/Y - 1/40

1/15 = 1/20 + 1/Y

Y = 60

question: In a class, there are 12 boys and 8 girls. Four students are selected at random. Find the probability that among selected students there are 3 boys and 1 girl.
solution:
Number of ways of selecting 4 students out of 20 students = 20C4

=> (20 * 19 * 18 * 17)/(4 * 3 * 2 * 1) = 4845

Number of ways of selecting 3 boys and 1 girl = 12C3 * 8C1

=> [(12 * 11 * 10)/(3 * 2)] * 8 = 1760

Required probability = 1760/4845 = 352/969

A and B can do a work in 25 days and (3R + 2) days respectively. The ratio of efficiency of A and B is 4:5 respectively. If B and C together can do the whole work in 40/3 days, then in how much time C alone can do the whole work?
solution:
Ratio of efficiency of A and B = 4:5

Time taken by A : Time taken by B = 5:4

25/(3R + 2) = 5/4

100 = 15R + 10

15R = 90

R = 6

Time taken by B = 3*6 + 2 = 20 days

Time taken by C = 1/(3/40 - 1/20) = 40 days = 7*6 - 2 = '7R - 2' days

question:
Question below consists of a question and two statements numbered I and II given below it. You have to decide whether the data provided in the statements are sufficient to answer the question. Read both the statements and give answer:

Present age of A and B together is 80% more than present age of C. Find the present age of B.

Statement I: Six years later, the ratio of age of A and C will be 2:3 respectively.

Statement II: Present average age of B and C is 33 years.
option_1: If the data in statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: If the data given in both statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: If the data in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: If the data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question.
option_5: If the data given in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.
solution:
A + B = 180% of C = 9C/5

From I:

(A + 6)/(C + 6) = 2/3

A = 2C/3 - 2

Statement I alone is not sufficient.

From II:

B + C = 2*33 = 66 years

B = 66 - C

Statement II alone is not sufficient.

From I and II together -

A + B = 9C/5

2C/3 - 2 + 66 - C = 9C/5

27C + 15C - 10C = 64*15

C = 30

A = 2*30/3 - 2 = 18

B = 66 - 30 = 36

So, present age of B = 36 years

Hence, option 'e' is correct.

question:
Question below consists of a question and two statements numbered I and II given below it. You have to decide whether the data provided in the statements are sufficient to answer the question. Read both the statements and give answer:

Total population of village A and B together are 1200. Find the illiterate population of villages A and B together.

Statement I: Illiterate population of villages A are 40 less than number of literate population of villages B.

Statement II: The ratio of literate population of villages B to illiterate population of villages B is 5:3.
option_1: If the data in statement I alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_2: If the data either in statement I alone or in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question.
option_3: If the data in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question, while the data in statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
option_4: If the data neither in statement I alone or in statement II alone is sufficient to answer the question.
option_5: If the data given in both statements I and II together are necessary to answer the question.
solution:
Let literate and illiterate population of village A is p and q respectively and literate and illiterate population of village B is r and s respectively.

Total population of village A and B together = 1200

p + q + r + s = 1200

From I:

Illiterate population of villages A = number of literate population of villages B - 40

q = r - 40

Statement I alone is not sufficient.

From II:

literate population of villages B / illiterate population of villages B = 5/3

r/s = 5/3

Statement II alone is not sufficient.

From I and II together:

q = r - 40

q = 5s/3 - 40

Statement I and II together is not sufficient.

Hence, option 'd' is correct.

question: A student scores 80 marks out of 100 in an exam in which the theory and practical sections are equally weighted. Assume his theory and practical scores are equal. If his theory marks were 10% higher, his overall score would become 83.2. By what percentage did his practical score change?
solution:
Since the two parts are equal and the total is 80, we take:

Theory = Practical = 40

With a 10% increase, theory score becomes (40 X 1.10) = 44

New overall score = 83.2

So, new practical score = 83.2 - 44 = 39.2

Change in practical score = 39.2 - 40 = - 0.8

i.e., (- 0.8/40) X 100 = - 2% change

question: Ratio of monthly income of three sisters Vatika, Mohita and Deepa is 9 : 5 : 7 and the ratio of their monthly saving is 5 : 3 : 8. If the highest income and highest saving of any of the sister is Rs 72000 and Rs 40000 respectively then what is the ratio of monthly expenditure of three sisters?
solution:
Ratio of monthly income of three sisters Vatika, Mohita and Deepa is 9 : 5 : 7 and it is also given that the highest income of any of the sister is Rs 72000.

From the given ratio we can see that income of Vatika is Rs 72000.

Hence Monthly income of Mohita and Deepa will be Rs 40000 and Rs 56000 respectively.

Now from the given ratio we can know that Deepa has the highest saving of Rs 40000.

So the savings of Vatika and Mohita will be Rs 25000 and Rs 15000 respectively.

Now monthly expenditure of Vatika = Rs (72000 - 25000) = Rs 47000

Monthly expenditure of Mohita= Rs (40000 - 15000) = Rs 25000 Monthly expenditure of Deepa = Rs (56000 - 40000) = Rs 16000

Therefore required ratio = 47000 : 25000 : 16000 = 47 : 25 : 16

question:
Directions:

Directions :Seven friends A, B, C, D, E, F, & G who are sitting in a row facing north lives on different floors of a same building. Ground floor of building is numbered 1 & topmost floor is numbered 7. They have different roll numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 & 7 (not necessarily in same order). None of the friends' floor number is equal to his roll number. Also, people living on consecutive floors & having consecutive roll numbers don't sit adjacent to each other.

• D whose roll number is second highest sits third to right of B who sits immediate right of person who lives in 6th floor.

• E whose roll number is 3 sits third to right of person who sits second to left of person who lives at topmost floor.

• Person who lives on 7th floor is not adjacent to both B & D.

• Person whose floor number is 5 sits immediate left of C

• B & A whose roll number is 5 are not adjacent but A's floor number is equal to B's roll number.

• F & G whose roll number is 4, sit one person between them.

• B's floor number is twice its roll number.

• People with roll number 7 & 4 don't sit at extreme ends.



Who lives on 4th floor?
solution:
• D whose roll number is second highest sits third to right of B who sits immediate right of person who lives in 6th floor.

• E whose roll number is 3 sits third to right of person who sits second to left of person who lives at topmost floor.

• Person who lives on 7th floor is not adjacent to both B & D.

• Also, no two-person living on consecutive floors sits adjacent to each other.

So, Case 1 will be eliminated.

• Person whose floor number is 5 sits immediate left of C.

• B & A whose roll number is 5 are not adjacent but A's floor number is equal to B's roll number.

• Also, people living on consecutive floors & having consecutive roll numbers don't sit adjacent to each other.

• F & G whose roll number is 4, sit one person between them. So, Case 3-b will be eliminated.

• B's floor number is twice its roll number.

So possible combinations for B(floor number, roll number) are B(2,1), B(4,2), B(6,3)

But B cannot be on floor 4 and 6 because then it will violate the condition that people living in consecutive floor don't sit adjacent.

So, B lives on floor 2 & B's roll number is 1. So, A floor number is 1.

• People living on consecutive floors & having consecutive roll numbers don't sit adjacent to each other.

• People with roll number 7 & 4 don't sit at extreme ends. So, Case 3-a will be eliminated.

This is the final arrangement.


E lives on 4th floor.

Directions:

Directions :Six persons D, K, M, R, T and W are sitting around a circular table facing the centre. All of them speak different foreign languages viz., Chinese, Spanish, French, Polish, Arabic and English but not necessarily in the same order.

Only two persons sit between K and T, who speaks Arabic language. R sits immediate right of W, who speaks French language. Neither K nor R speaks English. M sits second to the right of the person who speaks Arabic. The person who speaks English sits third to the left of the person who speaks Spanish. D sits immediate left of M and speaks Polish language.



Who among the following speaks Chinese language?
solution:
Only two persons sit between K and T, who speaks Arabic language.

M sits second to the right of the person who speaks Arabic.

D sits immediate left of M and speaks Polish language.

R sits immediate right of W, who speaks French language.

The person who speaks English sits third to the left of the person who speaks Spanish.

Neither K nor R speaks English.

Now, only Chinese language is remaining.

This is the final arrangement.


K speaks Chinese language.
